Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Movement Tracking System to Explore Embodiment and Cognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A multidisciplinary research team will acquire a motion capture system capable of precisely tracking human body movements while simultaneously recording brain activity and eye movements. The equipment will provide detailed insight into the nervous system’s role in planning and generating movements, as well as how the human mind perceives its own body. Scientists with expertise spanning psychology, neuroscience, computer science, rehabilitation engineering, and linguistics will use the system to answer a range of foundational research questions focusing on how cognitive processes are dynamically linked with motor action. The research will drive fundamental advances in low-cost virtual reality technologies, neurorehabilitation approaches for patients with motor deficits, and assistive frameworks for supporting age-related changes in attention. The equipment will also support cross-disciplinary educational and training opportunities for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students, as well as work in social cognition biases, human-robot interaction, workplace prejudice, and interactive art.

The 36-camera motion capture system with 64-channel wireless EEG and wireless eye tracking will provide detailed measurements of the moving body, including joint trajectories, motor path efficiencies, and timing information. The movement information is synchronized with brain activity recordings captured with a non-invasive wearable headcap using wireless electroencephalography (EEG) technology. EEG measures changes in electrical activity across the skull which indicate changes in brain activity levels. Planned research studies involve untethered movements to enable exploration of the concept of embodiment, which is the process by which a person develops a sense of self over an object. The researchers will explore embodiment of prosthetic limbs by amputees and embodiment of virtual bodies by users of virtual reality systems. Precise tracking of finger and mouth movements will enable the study of gestures during speech, and how they relate to the concept of embodiment, with an emphasis on how gestured speech changes with age-related declines in hearing and attention. The work will also describe how problems with embodiment lead to phantom limb pain, a pain syndrome experienced by a majority of people with amputations. The research enabled by this equipment will transform scientists’ understanding of how the brain and body interact to generate smooth and effective movements. Long-term impacts will fuel technological advances in human-computer interfaces, neurorehabilitation techniques, attentional-deficiency countermeasures, and virtual reality systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI provided funding for Rhodes College to acquire a high-precision motion capture (MoCap) system that allows for the tracking and quantification of human movement.  With this equipment, researchers are able to correlate movement trajectories, velocities and joint kinematics with simultaneous eye tracking information and brain activity recording data.   Rhodes dedicated a large space (2500 square feet) to permanently install this equipment in the center of campus (Ewing Studio).  The vision of this being an elite research system and space has come to life over the past few years.  It can be used by any community member, encouraging interdisciplinary work.  The college currently also supports a student worker whose sole job it is to maintain and help others use the system as well as an IT specialist. This lab was set up during the middle of the COVID pandemic so much of the installation was done by the tireless efforts of the PI team.  This a major contribution of this work was to set up the delicate equipment and devise a way for the community to use it into the future.  

As a broader impact, this equipment has a had a meaningful impact on the education and training that our students receive.  Students use the equipment directly in their undergraduate classes in acting, digital art and animation, computer science, neuroscience and psychology (touching over 50 students a year).  Currently, four faculty and over 15 students are using the equipment for research/creative activity. Many of these students have Rhodes internal fellowship funding for their projects and few low-income students were involved in research through an NSF S-STEM award.  Students are trained on how neuroscientists, computer scientists, behavioral scientists, and/or artists tackle specific problems or research questions in their fields. For those students working with faculty who conduct research, this training includes reviewing relevant literature, generating hypotheses, measuring human movements, behavior, and cognition, computer programming, data analysis and interpretation, and/or dissemination of research or creative work. For students working with creative arts faculty, this training includes translating human movements into digitally generated avatars for animation, processing real-time motion data for live performances, and designing interactive art experiences.  Undergraduate education and research with this equipment highlights interdisciplinary approaches. A small undergraduate college is a great place for this equipment as it has impacted many undergraduate students as well as the careers of faculty.  It has allowed students to have meaningful creative and research experiences, but it has allow many of our students to think more deeply about why this equipment is important to science and how it can be used to make an impact on our daily lives.

 

This work has also expanded the intellectual merit of our research communities.  The opportunities provided by the MRI equipment to contribute to meaningful research that expands our understanding of the neuroscientific principles underlying the sense of embodiment, and push improvements in virtual reality to make it more convincingly real so that VR can be a more powerful learning and training tool.   The equipment has also made important gesture research possible allowing the movements of speakers to be tracked while they engage in various narrative and storytelling tasks.  This research will provide important insight to gestures and other body movements as it relates to communication.
